statement.p: Graph the equation \displaystyle{y}={2}{\left({5}^{{{x}+{5}}}\right)}+{1}. You will select a point on the asymptote (only y coordinate matters); then you select two points on the exponential.

solution.p: Because \displaystyle{y}={2}{\left({5}^{{{x}+{5}}}\right)}+{1} has \displaystyle+{1} at the end, the asymptote is at \displaystyle{y}={1}.
One convenient point is where \displaystyle{x}+{5}={0} which is \displaystyle{x}=-{5}. Here \displaystyle{y}={3}.
A second convenient point is one right of -5, which is \displaystyle{x}=-{4}. Here \displaystyle{y}={11}
